article: When I was a kid, my mom liked to make breakfast food for dinner every now and then. And I remember one night in particular _ she had made breakfast after a long, _ day at work.  On that _ so long ago, my mom _ a plate of eggs, sausage and extremely _ biscuits in front of my dad. I remember _ to see if anyone noticed! Yet all my dad did was _ for his biscuit, smile at my mom and ask me how my day was at school. . . I don t _ what I told him that night, but I do remember watching him _ biscuits happily!  When I got up from the table that evening, I remember hearing my mom _ to my dad for burning the biscuits. And I ll never _ what he said: Honey, I love burned biscuits.  Later that night, I went to kiss Daddy _ night and I asked him if he _ liked his biscuits burned. He wrapped me in his arms and said, Your Momma put in a hard day at work today and she s really _ . And besides, a burned biscuit never _ anyone!  Life is full of imperfect things. . . and imperfect people. I m not the _ at hardly anything, but what I ve _ over the years is that learning to accept each other s faults, which is one of the most important keys to _ a healthy, growing, and lasting relationship.  We could extend this to any relationship. In fact, _ is the base of any relationship, be it a husband-wife or parent-child or friendship!  God Bless You. . . Now, and always. . .  So please _ me a biscuit, and yes, a burned one will be fine!
